--- Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Has anyone done any work on unit test for memory usage of objects?
> 
> What I'd like to do is write a unit tests that asserts the
> memory used by a certain object is less than a given value.
> Ideally I'd like to do deep measurements that follow a
> complete object graph. For example, you might measure that
> the total memory used by a list and all its members were
> less than 100K. [...]

At last year's JavaOne conference I ran across the "Insane" tool, a 
remarkably simple and small set of classes used by the NetBeans team 
to measure memory usage and detect memory leaks.  It can also 
estimate the size of object trees.

See:
http://performance.netbeans.org/insane/

Briefly, it uses reflection to find all the classes the system 
ClassLoader has loaded, and follows the static fields to all 
instances referenced by them.  And you can give it stack-based 
references to improve coverage.  It's a very nifty trick.
